page.title: 03The Deepcut Dig
page.content: The Frimley Railway Aqueduct was built to allow the railway to pass under the{Basingstoke Canal.}In 1900 the aqueduct was lengthened by two arches as the railway was widened. Trade on the canal declined and it was derelict by 1966 when it was partially restored. In 1977, 600 Canal Society volunteers arrived on the Deepcut flight of locks to begin{The {Deepcut Dig.}The amounts of materials used in{The Deepcut Dig}were: 10 tons of sand, 18 concrete mixers, 400 bags of cement, 90 tons of ballast, \ ton reinforcing material, 3500 bricks, 4 dumper trucks, 14 hand powered concrete breakers and 100s of power tools. 1400 pints of beer where drunk. Restoration of the canal continues. In 1981 British Rail drained and relined the aqueduct; 20 of the 29 locks are now working
